content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B{B} for the following reasons:

1. In this game, there is no dominant strategy that guarantees a higher payoff regardless of what my opponent chooses (R or B).

2. Since the game has 75 rounds and the payoffs are slightly different depending on whether both players choose R or B, it would be reasonable to assume that the opponent could adopt a similar reasoning process as well.

3. Given that both strategies yield positive expected values but R{R} results in a lower average payoff compared to B{B}, I would lean towards choosing B to maximize my earnings over the course of 75 rounds.

4. It is also important to note that the opponent's strategy could change during the game, which makes it difficult to predict their moves accurately. In this case, choosing B would still provide a positive expected value on average, even if the opponent were to change their strategy later in the game.

5. Lastly, since I am playing against an anonymous player, I have no way of knowing whether they will adjust their strategy based on my choices or not. Choosing B gives me the advantage of having a higher minimum expected payoff per round (40$) compared to choosing R (35$).
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

As a human player, I will stick with my previous choice of strategy B and continue with B{B}. It seems that my opponent made the same decision as me in the first round, resulting in both of us earning 40$ each. By continuing to choose B, I maintain the higher minimum expected payoff per round (40$) compared to choosing R (35$). Additionally, since my opponent has already shown that they are choosing B, there is no reason for me to deviate from my strategy at this point unless I have new information suggesting that my opponent may switch strategies.

You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

As a human player, I will stick with my previous choice of strategy B and continue with B{B}. If my opponent chooses R in this round, I would receive 35$ while they get nothing. While it may seem tempting to switch strategies at this point to take advantage of the situation where my opponent chose R, there are a few factors that make me hesitant to do so:

1. Choosing R now only gives me an additional 5$ compared to sticking with B. Over the course of 75 rounds, this small difference in payoff might not be significant enough to justify deviating from my initial strategy.

2. If I choose R now and my opponent continues choosing R for the rest of the game, they would earn a total of 35$ per round while I only receive 0$. This would result in them earning significantly more than me over the course of 75 rounds.

3. It is possible that my opponent may change their strategy later in the game, and by sticking with B, I maintain the higher minimum expected payoff per round (40$) compared to choosing R (35$).

Given these considerations, I will continue with B{B} for the next round.
